clinical_study.brief_title: Extended Recovery During COVID-19: Multi-perspective Value-based Analysis
clinical_study.official_title: The Rapid Conversion of Ordinary Recovery Beds to an Overnight Intensive Recovery (OIR) to Alleviate the High Pressure on Postoperative Intensive Care Demands During COVID-19 Pandemics in a Local Tertiary Hospital: a Multi-perspective Value-based Analysis

collaborator.agency: Anaesthesia & Operation Theatre Service, Tuen Mun Hospital, Hong Kong
Intensive Care Unit, Tuen Mun Hospital, Hong Kong

brief_summary.textblock: To evaluate the value-based effectiveness of the implementation of TMH Extended Recovery during COVID-19 pandemics by an institutional matched case-control and quantitative survey study Two ordinary recovery beds were converted to an overnight intensive recovery ("Extended Recovery") within the operating theatre complex of Tuen Mun Hospital during COVID-19 pandemics, in an attempt to free the ICU bed and resources from postoperative patients. This study was designed to evaluate the efficacy and staff perceptions towards the abrupt implementation of TMH Extended Recovery by mobilization of the existing OT resources to cope with the COVID-19 emergency situations. The value-based analysis would look into the implementation effectiveness in twofold: 1) the clinical efficacy using a case-control audit on clinical outcomes and 2) the staff acceptance by means of the staff attitudes survey . Hopefully this would provide a multi-perspective evaluation of the implementation strategies and aid planning of new services in the future.

detailed_description.textblock:
2 parts are included in this study
The Matched Case Control study, with the aim of analyzing the clinical efficacy of TMH Extended Recovery during COVID-19 in value based healthcare model. We included all postoperative patient admitted in TMH Extended Recovery during COVID epidemics, excluding patient awaiting ICU in the ordinary recovery room or patient requiring level 3 intensive care on arrival in the recovery room. Three activation periods of extended recovery service (10 Feb - 26 Apr 2020 / 27 Jul - 13 Sep 2020 / 4th wave, still ongoing), and performed case matching with the post operative patient with similar clinical characteristics entering intensive care unit directly in recent 3-5 years, with each case matched with specifically 5 control. We evaluate the value based health care efficacy, including the amount of healthcare expenditure based on bed occupancy and manpower, rate of elective discharge to intensive care unit from extended recovery, rate of unanticipated intensive care admission within 48hrs upon discharge to general ward, and length of hospital stay, and total number of ICU bed spared.
The staff attitude survey, with the aim to investigate the staff perception towards the implementation of TMH extended recovery during COVID-19 pandemics based on Technology Acceptance Model in healthcare. We designed a questionnaire based on Technology Acceptance Model, and distributed to medical and nursing staffs involved in extended recovery service, and evaluate the perceived usefulness, perceived ease of use, social influence of subjective norm, and perceived behavioral control of facilitating condition. Differential analysis would be conducted for the evaluation.

intervention.description: From January 2020, during COVID-19 first panademics in Hong Kong, a bundle of interim measures were implemented with the joint efforts of the Department of Anaesthesia and Operating Theatre Services (A&OT) and Intensive Care Unit (ICU), and two ordinary recovery beds were converted into Extended Recovery (ExRR), based on the concept of overnight intensive recovery (OIR) to provide level 2 intensive care to patients undergoing major or ultra-major operations or having multiple comorbidities warranted intensive care in the immediately postoperative periods. This was conducted over 3 panademics wave in Hong Kong.
intervention.arm_group_label: postoperative patients admitted to TMH Extended Recovery during COVID-19 pandemics

study_pop.textblock: o The operation periods of TMH Extended Recovery during COVID-19 and therefore the number of cases included in this study was largely bound by the administrative decision of hospital management based on the ICU bed pressure during COVID-19 situations. All patients being admitted to TMH Extended Recovery during the two periods of service activation amid COVID-19 pandemics, i.e. from 10 February 2020 to 26 April 2020 and from 27 July 2020 to 13 September 2020 were included in this audit. To increase the statistical power above 0.8, a control-to-case ratio of 5 will be adopted for case matching based on the assumption of having the correlation coefficient greater than 0.2 or the prevalence of exposure in the control group less than 0.15.
